misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented the wrong problem (distance between points instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The submitted program computes the Euclidean distance between two points instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges as required by the specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that submitting a solution that reads two 2D points and prints their distance is acceptable for this question, or they did not realize they were submitting code for a completely different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single numeric grade (0–100) from the user, then use conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to check which range it falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade value.
Program computes a square root of squared differences between coordinates rather than checking grade ranges.
Program outputs a numeric distance with a message about points, not a letter grade A–F.
There are no conditional statements (if/else) to implement grade thresholds.
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely a file or problem mix-up: the student copied or submitted a solution to a different exercise (distance between points) instead of implementing the specified grade calculator. There is no evidence in this file of any attempt to handle grade ranges or letter output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and ensure the code you write directly addresses it. Start a new class for the grade calculator that (1) reads one integer or double for the grade, (2) uses if/else-if/else chains to check which numeric range the grade falls into, and (3) prints the corresponding letter grade exactly as required.
related_concepts: Using if/else-if/else chains for range classification
Testing that input/output prompts match the assignment
Verifying you submitted the correct source file
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every line of the program is devoted to reading 2D coordinates and computing a distance, with no mention of grades, ranges, or letter outputs, strongly indicating the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: This entire program is dedicated to computing the distance between two points, with no code to read a grade, no conditionals for grade ranges, and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code solves the wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program for calculating the distance between two points, rather than the required Grade Calculator utilizing conditional logic (if/else if/else).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either believes this code fulfills the Grade Calculator requirement or accidentally submitted the wrong file for the assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read one numeric grade (0-100) and use if/else if statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four inputs (coordinates) instead of one (grade)
No conditional (if/else) grading logic is present
Output is a calculated distance, not a letter grade
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' is irrelevant to the task
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to adhere to the assignment prompt or an error in the submission process (submitting the wrong file).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please locate and submit the correct file that implements the Grade Calculator logic based on the required grade ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code structure, inputs, processing, and output clearly match a different assignment (Distance Between Points), leaving no doubt that the required Grade Calculator logic is entirely absent.

evidence.note: The class name confirms the incorrect assignment was submitted.
The code reads coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade input (0-100).

evidence.snippet:
System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n",
                Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The calculation and output are for distance, not a letter grade, indicating a complete failure to implement the required conditional logic.
